item.title: The $2 Rental Batteries Helping to Power South Africa
item.description: The batteries offer an affordable system for those who lack reliable power and the money to buy their own solar panels.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Joao Silva

media:content.media:description: Anselmo Mugabe, in stripy shirt, who runs a hair Salon in Thembisa, a township north east of Johannesburg, uses the BPowerD batteries in order to run his business.

item.title: Quote of the Day: She Wants to Die. Will Canada Let Her?
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 17, 2026.

item.title: A Refuge for Afghan Music Is at Risk of Falling Silent
item.description: Peshawar is a haven for Afghan artists who fled from the Taliban, which had banned music. A new policy of deportations by Pakistan threatens this community of exiles.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Asim Hafeez
item.category: Destruction of Cultural Antiquities and Heritage

media:content.media:credit: Asim Hafeez for The New York Times

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 17, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 17, 2026.

item.title: Quaint Contraction
item.description: Adam Aaronson’s tough themeless puzzle will get your head spinning.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:description: Levitating combatants at a 1999 taekwondo competition in Australia.

item.title: Rick Caruso Will Not Run for L.A. Mayor or California Governor in 2026
item.description: Mr. Caruso had the potential to shake up the contests for Los Angeles mayor or California governor.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler

media:content.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Rick Caruso, who lost his 2022 race for Los Angeles mayor, was considered a potential heavyweight as a candidate in 2026.

item.title: Read the Ruling Restricting Federal Agents’ Actions in Minnesota
item.description: A federal judge ruled in favor of protesters in the state.

item.title: Court Blocks Trump Administration From Freezing Food Stamps in Minnesota
item.description: With tensions high between the White House and the state, the ruling temporarily halted plans to withhold over $129 million in funding.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella

media:content.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A food pantry in Detroit Lakes, Minn., last year.

item.title: Judge Restricts Immigration Agents’ Actions Toward Minnesota Protesters
item.description: A federal judge ordered agents not to retaliate against people “engaging in peaceful and unobstructive protest activity” in the state and not to stop drivers who are not “forcibly obstructing” officers.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith

media:content.media:description: Minnesota residents have clashed with federal agents since late 2025, when the federal government began an immigration enforcement campaign that it named Operation Metro Surge.

item.title: Trump Administration Begins Criminal Inquiry Into Minnesota Leaders
item.description: The Justice Department’s investigation is a major escalation in the state-federal battle over the conduct of immigration agents in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Alan Feuer, Devlin Barrett and Jonah E. Bromwich

media:content.media:credit: Ryan Murphy for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jacob Frey, the mayor of Minneapolis, at a news conference this month. He and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota are being investigated by the Justice Department, according to a senior law enforcement official.

item.title: Trump Announces Members for Gaza ‘Board of Peace,’ Including Rubio and Kushner
item.description: The president also tapped a U.S. general to lead an international peacekeeping force that will be deployed to disarm Hamas and occupy Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gaza City on Tuesday. Most of Gaza has been destroyed by Israeli bombardment over more than two years of war.

item.title: AI Attack Ad in Texas Senate Race Shows John Cornyn Dancing With Jasmine Crockett
item.description: A video from Ken Paxton, a Republican primary challenger to Senator John Cornyn of Texas, depicted A.I.-generated imagery of the senator twirling with Jasmine Crockett, a Democratic Senate candidate.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein

media:content.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, is challenging Senator John Cornyn, a fellow Republican.

item.title: La FAA de EE. UU. advierte actividad militar sobre océanos de América Latina
item.description: Los siete avisos a los aviadores abarcaban zonas del océano Pacífico colindantes con México, Colombia, Ecuador y Panamá. Permanecerán vigentes hasta el 17 de marzo.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Un caza estadounidense F-35 despegando de un aeropuerto de Puerto Rico en diciembre.

item.title: Gabriel Barkay, 81, Dies; His Discoveries Revised Biblical History
item.description: One of Israel’s leading archaeologists, he found evidence that the writing of the Old Testament likely began much earlier than historians had thought.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

media:content.media:description: Gabriel Barkay in 2016, displaying a restored ancient tile excavated from the holy site in Jerusalem known to Jews as the Temple Mount. He earned a reputation as the “dean” of biblical archaeologists.

item.title: As Kennedy Center Rebrands It’s Mired in Black Tape
item.description: After the institution’s board declared it the Trump Kennedy Center, a lot of signage around the building is in the midst of a makeover.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A sign in an entryway to the parking garage of the Kennedy Center. Since the board voted to change the center’s name to include that of President Trump, black tape has begun to cover up signage that has the old name.

item.title: How ICE Tensions and Immigration Politics Could Shape 2026 Midterm Elections
item.description: Three reporters discuss the Minneapolis chaos and how it could play a role in the midterms.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck

media:content.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis.

item.title: Trump Has Machado’s Nobel Prize, but Neither Got What They Really Wanted
item.description: President Trump has María Corina Machado’s medal, but he is not recognized as the prize laureate. Ms. Machado did not win Mr. Trump’s endorsement to become Venezuela’s president.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: María Corina Machado’s decision to present her Nobel Peace Prize medal to President Trump has been met with mixed reviews in the United States and abroad.

item.title: By Raiding a Reporter’s Home, Is the F.B.I. Is Weaponizing National Security?
item.description: Knowing what the government is up to is essential for democracy to work.
item.dc:creator: David Schulz

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times

item.title: The Underachiever in Chief?
item.description: How much has Trump actually accomplished one year into his second term? According to the conservative analyst Yuval Levin, not much.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: Conservative Politics Can’t Just Be About Hate
item.description: Politics in America has taken an ugly turn, the conservative analyst Yuval Levin says on “The Ezra Klein Show,” arguing it has become too influenced by fear.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: Thousands Evicted From Makoko, the ‘Venice of Nigeria’
item.description: Community leaders in Lagos say evictions in the name of development have left many residents of this fishing village homeless.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Taiwo Aina

media:content.media:credit: Taiwo Aina for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: At the Makoko community, in Lagos, this week.

item.title: No Link Between Acetaminophen in Pregnancy and Autism, a New Study Finds
item.description: The review looked at more than three dozen studies and found no evidence that acetaminophen increased the risk of neurodevelopmental disorders in children.
item.dc:creator: Azeen Ghorayshi

item.title: Syria’s President Affirms Kurds’ Rights, in Overture to the Minority
item.description: President Ahmed al-Sharaa’s announcement comes after days of deadly clashes between government and Kurdish forces that have underscored the difficulty he faces in uniting the country.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum

media:content.media:description: People crossing a bridge as they flee from a Kurdish-controlled area, in Rasm al-Harmal, east of Aleppo, on Friday.

item.title: Bobi Wine, Ugandan Opposition Leader, Was Abducted, His Party Says
item.description: Mr. Wine’s party said on X that “an army helicopter” had landed in his compound and “forcibly” taken him away ahead of election results in Uganda, during a nationwide internet blackout.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

media:content.media:description: Supporters of the opposition leader Bobi Wine in Kampala, Uganda, on Monday.

item.title: F.A.A. Urges ‘Caution’ Over Oceans in Latin America, Warning of Military Activity
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration released seven advisories warning pilots to stay away from parts of the Pacific Ocean near Mexico, Colombia, Ecuador and Panama.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: An American F-35 fighter jet taking off from an airport in Puerto Rico in December.

item.title: Man Who Attacked ‘Grandpa Vicha’ in San Francisco Is Found Not Guilty of Murder
item.description: Instead, the man was convicted of lesser charges, including involuntary manslaughter, in the death of Vicha Ratanapakdee. The killing became a symbol of rising attacks against Asians during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin

media:content.media:description: Monthanus Ratanapakdee with a picture of her father, Vicha Ratanapakdee, in 2021. Mr. Ratanapakdee was shoved to the ground while out on a walk in San Francisco that year, and died from his injuries.

item.title: Edison Files Claims Against Los Angeles County and Others on Eaton Fire
item.description: Southern California Edison said its equipment most likely started the Eaton fire but asserted that government agencies and other businesses shared liability for the devastation.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Jill Cowan

media:content.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Eaton fire killed 19 people and destroyed more than 9,400 buildings in Southern California.

item.title: U.S. Boardings of Oil Tankers Reflect Hard Lessons Learned at Sea
item.description: Videos show U.S. forces descending quickly from helicopters onto the tankers, two years after a tragic boarding attempt.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: The oil tanker Marinera, previously known as Bella 1, was seized by the U.S. Coast Guard and seen off the coast of Scotland this week.

item.title: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to Warrants for Phone Location Data
item.description: The case involves a challenge to so-called geofence warrants, which permit law enforcement officials to sweep up location data of people near crime scenes.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle

media:content.media:description: The Call Federal Credit Union in Midlothian, Va., in 2020. The legality of a warrant for cellular phone data from an area around the bank is at question.

item.title: Trump Sets Convicted Fraudster Free for a Second Time
item.description: Also, the C.I.A. director met Venezuela’s new leader in Caracas. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump with reporters at the White House today.

item.title: An Antarctic Icebreaker Takes a Pioneering Sail
item.description: Part of Pine Island Glacier collapsed several years ago, forming an unstable inlet where no ship had sailed. Until now.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong

media:content.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: How to Take a Phone-Free Vacation
item.description: Five getaways, and other tips for disengaging on holiday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Kronsberg

item.title: Judge Recommends U.S. Issue Visa to Student Who Was Deported in Error
item.description: A federal prosecutor apologized this week, saying an ICE officer made a “mistake” in deporting Any Lucia López Belloza, a college freshman in Massachusetts, to Honduras.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

media:content.media:credit: Any Lucia Lopez Belloza's attorney, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Any Lucia López Belloza celebrating her high school graduation in Texas last year. She was attending college in Massachusetts before her deportation in November.

item.title: WestJet Backpedals on Economy Seats That Don’t Recline
item.description: WestJet, Canada’s second-largest carrier, backpedaled on a new seating plan after videos of crammed travelers went viral on social media.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung

media:content.media:credit: Jeff Mcintosh/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: WestJet had narrowed the distance between one row of seats and the next to 28 inches from about 30 inches.

item.title: The High Cost of ICE’s Low Standards
item.description: By doubling its force while slashing training time, ICE has scaled up its culture of violence into an unrestrained and unaccountable machine.
item.dc:creator: Kathleen Kingsbury, Lauren Dominguez Chan and Ingrid Holmquist

item.title: Walter Steding, Otherworldly One-Man Band and Portraitist, Is Dead at 75
item.description: A self-taught musician, he wore flashing goggles while playing the violin. But his real skill was as a painter, and his portraits offered an eerie commentary on the times.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: Trump Administration Delays Forced Collections on Student Loan Defaults
item.description: The Education Department has temporarily paused a plan to seize tax refunds and begin garnishing the wages of borrowers who have defaulted on their student loans.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard

media:content.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Education Department said it was postponing its plan to gradually resume garnishing the wages of those who have defaulted on their student loans.
